Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Koç University Rumelifeneri Yolu Sariyer Istanbul 34450 Turkey Graphical abstract Supported palladium catalysts are indispensable in a wide range of industries, including petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and the automotive sector. The dispersion of palladium within these catalysts, primarily determined by the average nanoparticle size, significantly influences both the catalytic properties and the utilization efficiency of palladium. This study explores the relationships between various catalyst synthesis parameters and the resulting Pd nanoparticle size/dispersion. We developed a machine learning (ML) model to guide future synthesis efforts aimed at achieving specific palladium dispersion levels. Data were collected from previous studies on supported Pd catalysts published between 2000 and 2023, encompassing 1543 distinct catalysts. Of these, 1295 data points were used to construct the ML model. Key synthesis parameters—such as synthesis method, metal loading, support type, support surface area, metal precursor, solvent, solvent pH, support’s point of zero charge, and calcination/reduction conditions—were identified as independent variables, while dispersion and average Pd nanoparticle size served as dependent variables. A random forest (RF) regression model was employed to predict dispersion (in %), validated through 5-fold cross-validation. The model achieved root mean squared errors (RMSE) of 9.5 (training) and 14.9 (testing) in Pd dispersion (in %) prediction. Experimental synthesis of new supported palladium catalysts using different synthesis parameters confirmed the model’s predictions, yielding an RMSE of 5.4. Additionally, data from the literature published in 2024 were also used to validate the model, the comparison resulted in an RMSE of 5.9. This ML approach offers significant potential for precisely controlling palladium dispersion during catalyst synthesis, moving beyond traditional trial-and-error methods. It holds a broad potential to significantly improve palladium utilization across a variety of industrial applications. Keywords Supported Pd catalyst Machine learning Heterogeneous catalysts Catalyst synthesis Association rule mining Random forest Data availability All data have been shared in GitHub. The related link is provided in the manuscript. The database is also shared as a separate Supplementary Material file as well. 1 Introduction Supported palladium catalysts are essential in numerous industrial applications, from petrochemicals to pharmaceuticals. In 2022, the global palladium market was valued at over 16.5 billion USD and is projected to reach 24 billion USD by 2030 [1]. This demand is driven by the catalytic properties of palladium, which are highly dependent on the structural characteristics of the active sites, especially in structure-sensitive reactions [2,3]. In 1969, Boudart introduced the concept of structure-sensitive reactions, highlighting the crucial role of nanoparticle size in determining the catalytic efficiency of supported metal catalysts [2]. This structural dependence presents an opportunity to optimize catalytic performance by precisely tuning the nanoparticle size to suit specific reactions [4,5]. A key factor in optimizing Pd catalysts is metal dispersion, which refers to the fraction of metal atoms available as active sites for catalysis. Metal dispersion is closely linked to nanoparticle size: large nanoparticles typically have low dispersion with active sites concentrated on the terrace regions, while smaller nanoparticles exhibit higher dispersion, with more active sites at the edges and corners. For noble metals like palladium, catalytic activity is highly sensitive to the location of metal atoms on the nanoparticle surface, making control over nanoparticle size critical for maximizing catalytic performance. Numerous studies have explored the relationship between nanoparticle size and catalytic activity in Pd catalysts [6,7]. Kawabata et al. found that the catalytic activity in hydrodechlorination reactions increased as Pd nanoparticle size decreased on Al-MCM-41-supported Pd catalysts [8]. Murata et al. observed that Pd/γ-Al2O3 showed a monotonic increase in turnover frequency (TOF) with increasing nanoparticle size, while Pd/α-Al2O3 and Pd/θ-Al2O3 exhibited a volcano-shaped dependence [9]. Similarly, Gopinath et al. demonstrated that smaller Pd nanoparticles enhanced catalytic activity and stability in hydrodechlorination of chlorobenzene, with deactivation accelerating as the nanoparticle size increased [10]. Binder et al. confirmed that the optimal nanoparticle size for Pd supported on SiO2 and TiO2 in ethene hydrogenation was around 3–4 nm [11]. These findings underscore the importance of controlling nanoparticle size to optimize both metal dispersion and catalytic performance. Despite extensive research, controlling metal dispersion remains challenging due to the complex interplay of synthesis parameters, such as precursor type, solvent, and post-synthesis treatments like calcination and reduction [12]. The synergistic effects of these factors on Pd dispersion are not fully understood, it is partly because the high number of variables involved. Addressing this knowledge gap is crucial for advancing the rational design of Pd catalysts with tailored properties. Machine learning (ML) has proven to be a powerful tool for predicting experimental outcomes and modeling complex processes involving many variables [13]. In materials science, ML is increasingly used to design and discover new materials by screening large datasets and correlating molecular properties with performance. This approach relies on experimental and computational databases such as ICSD [14], CSD [15], The Materials Project [16], and NOMAD [17], as well as density functional theory (DFT) simulations. ML has been successfully applied in fields like metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [18], halide perovskites [19], membranes [20], and battery materials [21]. Recently, the use of large language models like ChatGPT has extended to materials research as well, though legal and ethical concerns remain [22,23]. In catalysis, ML can be applied to understand the complex, multicomponent nature of catalysts, which often exhibit different behaviours depending on the reaction conditions [24,25]. While molecular properties influence catalytic performance, macroscopic factors, such as metal dispersion, surface area, and pore distribution, also play critical roles. To address these challenges, ML-based catalyst design must follow a multilevel approach: Initially, ML models can correlate molecular descriptors (e.g., electronic and structural properties) with catalytic performance, based on data from molecular simulations or experimental databases. This allows the screening of large numbers of model systems to identify promising candidates [26,27]. Next, ML can be used to predict macroscopic properties like metal dispersion, integrating molecular descriptors with experimental data [28]. Finally, ML models can estimate catalyst performance under real-world conditions by combining microscopic and macroscopic descriptors with operational factors like temperature, pressure, and feed composition [29,30]. This multilevel framework is essential for designing catalysts that perform efficiently under practical conditions. While ML models based on model systems offer valuable insights, they are limited to idealized conditions. Models relying on experimental performance data from literature, on the other hand, face two main challenges. First, there exists a wide variety of reactions and the lack of standardized protocols on each of these reactions leads to data from varying experimental conditions that are hard to compare, despite the efforts to develop FAIR-compliant catalysis databases [31]. Second, many models are 'black-box' in nature, as experimental procedures and parameters are reported without detailing crucial catalyst properties like dispersion or particle size, particularly in the working state. As a result, high-performance conditions identified are hard to generalize due to a lack of understanding of the underlying mechanisms. Hence, to realize such multilevel framework for designing catalysts, reliable models connecting the synthesis parameters to key macroscopic properties—such as metal dispersion—are required. Metal dispersion significantly impacts the catalyst performance, but predicting it remains challenging due to the complex synthesis parameters involved. This highlights the need for a data-driven approach to correlate synthesis conditions with metal dispersion, offering a pathway for the rational design of catalysts. By addressing this gap, ML can be leveraged to optimize catalyst properties, improving the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of Pd utilization in real-world applications. This work aims to bridge this gap by developing an ML model to predict metal dispersion based on synthesis parameters, offering a systematic approach to designing Pd catalysts with optimal properties. We collected data from 361 articles published between 2000 and 2023, focusing on the relationship between synthesis parameters and Pd dispersion or nanoparticle size. The resulting dataset, which includes 1543 catalysts, has been made publicly available on GitHub. We first present a pre-analysis of the dataset, followed by the development of ML models to predict Pd dispersion. Finally, we validate the models by comparing their predictions with new experimental data from this work and literature published after January 2024. Our results demonstrate that these ML models hold significant potential for guiding the design of Pd catalysts with tailored structures, leading to improved and more efficient use of Pd metal. 2 Methodology 2.1 Construction of the dataset The dataset, consisting of 361 articles published between 2000 and 2023, includes a total of 1543 instances, each representing a separate supported palladium catalyst. Of these, 1295 instances were used for analysis and the construction of the ML models. The selected articles were found via Scopus and Web of Science by using keywords “Pd catalysts” or “supported Pd catalysts” with the search option “appearing anywhere in the document”. The dataset includes information related to the supported Pd catalyst synthesis parameters and corresponding Pd dispersion and average nanoparticle size results. List of input/output variables and their ranges/categories are given in Supplementary Material (SM) Table S1. The complete dataset is provided in a Microsoft Excel file (Supported Pd Catalysts Model Data.xlsx), where collected data points (raw data), organized data points (dataset of the model), and pre-analysis results are presented and it can be downloaded via provided Github link (https://github.com/kubra-tiras/Pd_CatalystSynthesis_ML_Model) or can be found in the SM. In the data collection process, studies were selected with the consideration of the given synthesis information and the availability of the data from average palladium nanoparticle size or palladium dispersion measurements. Data collection was conducted objectively without prioritizing any specific journal or research group. The aim was to capture related information on a wide range of preparation procedures. The selected articles were first classified based on their synthesis techniques categorized into eight different groups: Impregnation, deposition–precipitation, liquid-phase reduction, sol–gel, ion-exchange, photo-deposition, polyol, and microwave-assisted synthesis [32–38]. Definition of these methods are provided in Table S2, SM. In the synthesis of supported heterogeneous catalysts, researchers often prefer impregnation methods owing to their simplicity. While impregnation methods offer ease of application and successful anchoring of the metal nanoparticles on support surface, the control on the interaction between the support and the metal remains limited [32]. Most common impregnation methods are wet impregnation (WI) and incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) techniques. Although impregnation methods do not offer strong control over metal nanoparticle size, post-treatment conditions can be a way to achieve desired dispersion and average metal nanoparticle size [32]. The second most common synthesis method in the collected data was determined as deposition–precipitation method. Studies that preferred deposition–precipitation method commonly used Na2CO3 as the reducing agent and involve pH adjustment. Precipitation method was also noted as deposition–precipitation in the dataset because of the same logic behind these techniques [33]. The third most used method was the liquid-phase reduction method (reductive deposition) [32]. In this study, the differences between these synthesis methods introduced by the researchers were discussed via pre-analysis methods. After the synthesis method was noted in the dataset, other variables were decided and collected based on the information available in the articles (frequency of appearance) and past experiences on supported metal catalyst synthesis (domain knowledge). Pd dispersion (given in %) and average size of the Pd nanoparticles (given in nm) were selected as the output variables and the parameters related to synthesis conditions, including the synthesis method, metal loading, support type, support’s surface area, metal precursor, solvent type, solvent’s pH, support’s point of zero charge (PZC), and support’s calcination/calcination/reduction conditions, were selected as the input variables (descriptors). Two of the descriptors were decided as PZC values of support materials and the pH of the precursor solution to reflect the importance of metal precursor-support interaction and its effect on the final metal dispersion. Zhu and coworkers explained the limitation of IWI, where there is no control over metal-support interaction [39]. They suggested that this interaction can be improved via using electrostatic adsorption mechanisms and introduced “charge-enhanced dry impregnation” [39]. PZC values of support materials indicate the pH value at which the support surface is neutral; and it is a crucial factor for the selection of metal precursor [39]. Zhu and coworkers explained that selecting cationic metal precursors for the supports with low PZC, such as SiO2, and preferring anionic metal precursors for the supports with high PZC, such as Al2O3, can be a way to improve metal dispersion and achieve strong metal-support interaction [39]. In the dataset, this opposite correlation between Pd precursor solution pH and support PZC was investigated, and metal-support interaction was highlighted with the help of electrostatic interaction discussion. However, the support’s PZC values were not mentioned in most of the articles present in the dataset. To be able to consider the possible effects of this parameter, the report by Kosmulski, which tabulates the PZC values of various metal oxides (along with the information where those materials were obtained), was used for estimating the corresponding PZC values of the supports used for the related synthesis [40]. The estimation information for PZC was added to the “Support PZC Reference” column of the dataset. In the dataset, the most common techniques used to determine the average metal nanoparticle size and/or metal dispersion were noted as: H2 Chemisorption, CO Chemisorption, O2 Chemisorption, (Scanning) Transmission Electron Microscope ((S)TEM), and X-Ray Diffraction (XRD). Chemisorption techniques are promising to measure dispersion, especially when the average nanoparticle size is less than 1 nm, for which TEM (unless it offers atomic resolution) and XRD fall short of providing reliable estimate on the average particle size [4]. Thus, in the “nanoparticle size” column presented in the dataset, the chemisorption results are prioritized compared to the results presented based on the TEM and XRD measurements. If the article provided the average Pd nanoparticle size based on the chemisorption result, it was used in the model as provided. If it was given based on the TEM and XRD measurements, the corresponding value from the TEM was preferred for the analysis because of the assumptions and limitations of metal crystallite size determination from the XRD (Scherrer equation) measurements [41,42]. The size information obtained by the XRD measurements was used only if the data either by TEM or chemisorption measurements were missing. Each data point in the dataset has the information on at least one of the output variables (metal dispersion or average metal nanoparticle size). While any missing input variable not provided in the corresponding article was estimated using the general trend obtained by the pre-analysis of the dataset (given in Table S3, SI), missing output variable (either Pd dispersion or average nanoparticle size) was estimated by using the relation between the two output variables. For this purpose, first, the correlation constant between the dispersion and average nanoparticle size was determined using the data points where both dispersion and average nanoparticle size were provided. The largest dataset of average Pd nanoparticle size and dispersion results reported together belongs to the articles where CO chemisorption was performed to determine the Pd dispersion. 136 instances in the dataset includes information on the Pd dispersion measured via CO chemisorption and average Pd nanoparticle size measured by TEM. Fig. 1 demonstrates how the palladium dispersion and the inverse of the average nanoparticle size (nm−1) of these 136 instances varies and identifies the correlation constant as 1.09. We used this constant to estimate any of the missing output parameter in the rest of the dataset using the given information. We note that there are data points that deviate from the expected relationship in Fig. 1. This deviation may be attributed to the method used for calculating the average particle size, particularly when the particle size distribution is broad. Specifically, average metal nanoparticle sizes below 2 nm require special consideration [43], as some nanoparticles on the surface may be smaller than the microscope's resolution limit. Besides, the difference between the actual and theoretical metal loadings were calculated to assess the accuracy of any given synthesis technique in matching the desired metal loading as follows: (1) A D ( % ) = ∑ n = 1 N T h e o r e t i c a l m e t a l l o a d i n g ( w t . % ) - A c t u a l m e t a l l o a d i n g ( w t . % ) T h e o r e t i c a l m e t a l l o a d i n g ( w t . % ) N x 100 where N is the number of instances where both theoretical and actual metal loading in wt.% were provided for that synthesis method. For the preliminary analysis of the dataset, the precursor cost factor (PCF) was defined. It was calculated by determining the cost of 1 g of palladium for each precursor and normalizing it to the lowest value among all palladium precursors in the pool. The prices were collected from the same brand (Sigma Aldrich) by using the product with the maximum weight available for the corresponding Pd precursor. Furthermore, the articles presenting novel catalyst synthesis procedures were excluded in the dataset to avoid inaccuracy in the model along with those with missing crucial information (i.e., absence of metal loading). Moreover, articles which used MOFs and zeolites as support were excluded from the dataset as well; as the final dispersion of the metal in these catalysts strongly depends on the support morphology [44]. 2.2 Analysis of dataset and development of ML models Pre-analysis of the dataset was done using simple descriptive statistics. Before predictive modelling was studied, the dispersion distribution was also checked. And the initial analysis of the dispersion distribution showed a right-skewed pattern, as provided in Fig. S1, which is consistent with expectations, as higher dispersion values are challenging to achieve and rarely reported. To improve the performance of the model, the dispersion data was firstly log-transformed, resulting in a more normal-like distribution, which can be clearly seen when Fig. 2 is compared with Fig. S1. Predictive modelling for Pd dispersion (%) was done using Random Forest (RF) algorithm. RF algorithms were used for regression purposes. The models were developed using 80–20 % train-test split ratio and five-fold cross validation. R language is used in the development of the models and rpart, Boruta, and randomForest packages were utilized [45–47]. The maximum features (mtry) and number of trees (ntree) parameters were tuned as hyperparameters. Hyperparameters giving the lowest root mean square error (RMSE) or highest accuracy were selected, and the performance of the optimum model were tested on the test set. Grid search was used to find the best hyperparameter set and mtry of 5 and ntree of 500 were selected as the best model for Pd dispersion (in %) prediction. Feature importance of the variables was done using Boruta analysis [45]. The missing values in the descriptors were filled with the mean/mode of the training set or the decided value and the details were given in Table S3, in the SM. The Pd dispersion (in %) predictive model resulted in 9.5 and 14.9 RMSE for training and testing, respectively. Association Rule Mining (ARM) method was used to relate the input and output variables and indicate the values or interval of the input variables to attain a specific level of performance. All descriptors were discretized and correlations between variables and output variables are assessed using a series of if-then statements using three parameters: support, confidence and, lift. Support indicates the frequency of the item (i.e. values or levels of input variable) in a dataset having a specific performance level. For example, IWI as a synthesis method is commonly seen in the dataset. Support value for IWI is calculated by dividing number of data points where IWI is used and resulted to particle size (let say <2 nm) to the total number of data points and it is found 0.03. Confidence, on the other hand, shows the frequency of true if-then statements. For instance, if-then statement is selected as if IWI method is selected, then an average nanoparticle size of <2 nm is achieved again. Confidence indicates the fraction of <2 nm data in all data containing IWI, and it is calculated as 0.11 in the dataset. Lastly, lift is used to understand the ratio between confidence and expected confidence. Here, expected confidence implies the scenario where there is no pattern, and the association rule is independent. Thus, lift shows whether there are truly an association between the parameters, or they have happened to be seen together in certain times in the dataset randomly. It can be described as fraction of datapoints having a specific input value or level (for example the use IWI) and desired outcome (for example <2 nm) divided by fraction of <2 nm data in the entire dataset; consequently, the lift value equal to one indicate that the effect of that input value on the output is just in the average level while higher lift values show the possibility to obtain much better performance with that input value. ARM analysis was performed in RStudio using apriori algorithm [48]. The levels of the discretization were given in Table S4, in the SM. Decision tree algorithms were also used to relate the input and output variables further and develop heuristic rules indicating the combination of input variables that may be used together to achieve desirable results. As the decision tree model from the entire dataset was too complicated to deduce any practical rule, the models were built for the common supports in the dataset (γ-Al2O3- and carbon-supported Pd catalysts) using 80–20 % train-test split ratio and five-fold cross validation. The decision tree algorithms were studied for two dispersion levels as high (≥22.2 % Pd dispersion) and low (<22.2 % Pd dispersion). Hyperparameters (minimum split (minsplit), complexity parameter (cp) and maximum depth (maxdepth)) were tuned by considering the accuracy and the simplicity of the tree [49]. The minsplit, maxdepth and cp were set as 10, 30, and 0.01 for γ-Al2O3-supported; 2, 30, and 0.01 for carbon-supported. The categories for decision trees were given in Table S5, in the SM. 2.3 Experimental validation of the ML models To test the validity of the ML models in predicting the palladium dispersion based on the synthesis parameters, a few supported palladium catalysts were synthesized with different synthesis parameters. For this purpose, Pd(NO3)2·xH2O (Aldrich) and PdCl2 (Aldrich) were used as palladium precursors. γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar), MgO (Merck), TiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich), and SiO2 prepared from fumed silica (Aldrich) were used as the supports. For the calcination of supports and dried catalysts, a Nabertherm P330 muffle furnace was used. The prepared catalysts were then reduced under 10 vol% H2 in balance Ar (Air Liquide). The materials which were used for CO chemisorption experiments were 5 vol% CO in He supplied from Elite Gaz and pure helium (99.9999 vol%) which was purchased from Air Liquide. In the catalyst synthesis, IWI was selected owing to its commonness in the collected data. The other synthesis conditions selected are provided in Tables S6 and S7, in the SM. A Micrometrics Autochem II 2920 analyzer was used for dynamic CO pulse chemisorption analysis on the synthesized catalysts. Approximately 40 mg of the calcined catalysts were reduced under H2/Ar flow at corresponding reduction temperatures (300–400 °C) for 1–2 h. Then, samples were cooled down to 25 °C under He flow, held at room temperature for 1 hr. After that, CO chemisorption was performed using 5 vol% CO in balance He (Elite Gaz) flow at the same temperature. The stoichiometric factor of CO:Pd was taken as 1:1 for Pd dispersion measurements [50–53]. Additionally, new test data were gathered from literature published in 2024, focusing on articles that presented supported Pd catalysts synthesized using techniques other than the IWI method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Pre-Analysis of the dataset The dataset was analysed first by using some simple descriptive statistics to understand the structure of the data and effects of descriptors on the palladium dispersion. Fig. 3 shows the distribution of data among the synthesis methods used. As demonstrated in Fig. 3a the researchers prefer to use the impregnation techniques (927 out of 1295 instances). Although the raw data includes novel synthesis methods, the dataset was organized to exclude 67 instances involving these advanced techniques, as they were too complex to summarize with the selected descriptors. However, these methods are still presented in the raw data noted as gas-phase cluster beam deposition, reverse micelle method, atomic layer deposition, sonication, encapsulating. In the selection of the synthesis method, researchers consider several factors. The first factor is the simplicity. Ideally, synthesis methods should offer low operational cost and avoid complex procedures which might cause deviations between different batches. Impregnation techniques appear as an outstanding choice based on meeting these expectations. Dispersion distribution based on the synthesis method was also assessed in Fig. 3b. In general, the highest dispersion data points belong to impregnation techniques, which can be directly related to high frequency of this method. It appears that deposition–precipitation, WI, and IWI resulted in the percent distribution between 0–100 %, while more data accumulated between 0–40 % in WI and IWI; however, the data also show that higher dispersions are also possible with these methods. The remaining methods, on the other hand, seemed to give only lower dispersion values. Especially, sol–gel, polyol, photo-deposition methods do not represent any Pd dispersion value higher than 50 % even though data for these methods are not sufficient to generalize. Another important aspect in the selection of the synthesis method is related to the amount of metal precursor needed for a given target metal loading. Pd is an expensive metal and achieving a desired metal loading in the synthesis is crucial. Hence, the synthesis method must offer a strong control over the metal loading. To understand the success of various synthesis methods on achieving the desired metal loading, both theoretical and actual metal loading values were collected for the dataset. While theoretical metal loading indicates the researcher’s target value, the actual metal loading shows the final metal loading that they reached after the synthesis. Fig. 3c shows the AD value determined from Eq. (1) for various methods. It appears that microwave-assisted synthesis, which has the highest AD value of 26 % and hence does not offer a strong control over the metal loading and the loss of Pd precursor solution is expected. Among the methods considered, WI techniques show the lowest AD value, 8.6 %. As introduced in Methodology, IWI uses a controlled amount of solvent, which is different from WI. It is of particular interest that WI has a lower AD value than IWI (AD: 15 %). The reason behind this situation can be related to the difference in higher number of instances with WI. While dataset covers 561 instances with WI, it includes 366 data points for IWI. Support selection demonstrated in Fig. 4 a indicates the predominance of carbon and alumina supported Pd catalysts in the dataset. Carbon is a widespread choice of support in catalytic systems because of its high surface area, stability under high temperature conditions, good resistance to acidic and basic environment, and its availability [54]. Different types of carbon materials appear as a possible preference for researchers. In the reported studies, activated carbon, mesoporous carbon, carbon monoliths, graphene, carbon black, carbon nanotubes, carbon nano globules, carbon crystallites, microcrystalline cellulose were used. The fundamental difference of these supports is that their surface areas are quite different from each other. For instance, while wood-based activated carbon is offering an average surface area in the order of 1000 m2/g, graphite offers only approximately 10 m2/g [55,56]. Carbon black and activated carbon can be seen as the common preference between these different carbon sources, which is related to the high surface area of these materials. It should be noted that carbon sources are the determining factors for pre- or post-treatment decisions. For instance, use of carbon supports eliminates any calcination treatment in the synthesis. The dispersion distributions for common supports are shown in Fig. 4b. This distribution illustrates the complexity of understanding the relationship between metal dispersion and support selection. The higher Pd dispersion results (>75 %) were mostly common for alumina supports, which was followed by cerium oxide. It appears that carbon and γ-Al2O3 supported Pd catalysts exhibit a dispersion distribution resembling a normal distribution, with a tail extending toward higher dispersion values. The prevalence of these supports in the dataset aligns with the normal distribution, while the tail suggests that achieving higher dispersion values is certainly possible. The unique feature of cerium oxide as support was previously introduced by de Souza and coworkers [57]. Their data showed the presence of a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies on the Pd/CeO2 compared to Pd/Al2O3, Pd/TiO2, and Pd/ZrO2. It is known that the strong metal-support interaction can be achieved by the support oxygen vacancies, and it might be the reason for achieving a high Pd dispersion when the support is CeO2 as shown in Fig. 4b [58]. Even though most of the studies preferred a palladium loading of 1–5 wt%, low (<0.5 wt%) and high (>20 wt%) palladium loadings were also applied in several studies. Fig. 5 a presents the distribution of Pd loading in the dataset. Pd loading preference differs for carbon-supported catalysts compared to metal oxide-supported ones. In Fig. 5b, while working with Pd/C, researchers preferred to select higher loadings, which might be linked to the high surface area of the carbon-based materials. Variation of Pd dispersion results with Pd loading are illustrated in Fig. 5b. The results show that it is possible to achieve any Pd dispersion value with metal loadings which are less than <1 wt%. The analysis indicates that, regardless of support type, synthesizing at high metal loadings (>10 wt%) is unlikely to achieve palladium dispersions greater than approximately 40 %. This means that approximately 60 % of the palladium loaded into the catalyst remains inaccessible to the reactants at such high Pd loadings. Precursor selection directly controls the cost of the catalyst. In Table 1 , the cost of popular Pd precursors were compared by defining their PCF values. Since the Pd precursors in Table 1 contain varying mass percentages of Pd, the corresponding prices must be normalized per unit mass of Pd. While PdCl2 appears to be the least expensive option with a PCF of 1.00, Pd(NH3)4 (NO3)2 is found to be the most expensive one with a PCF of 2.06—so to supply 1 g of Pd using this precursor is approximately two-times more expensive than using PdCl2. The difference between PCF values highlights the importance of understanding the influence of precursor selection on the metal dispersion. The frequency of these precursors in the dataset and their corresponding PCF values were found to be directly linked to each other as shown in Fig. 6 a with Pd(acac)2, Pd(NO3)2, and PdCl2 are being the most commonly used precursors with their lower PCF values. As expected from the price comparison, the most common precursor is identified as PdCl2. Pd dispersion distributions for PdCl2 in Fig. 6b indicates that PdCl2 is an excellent choice with its low PCF value and its potential to achieve desired metal dispersion. However, use of chlorine-based precursors requires special care for the complete removal of this ion from the final catalyst, as any remnants of Cl- ion on the surface might directly influence the surface characteristics of the support and modify the dispersion and electronic structure of the metal centres [59]. During the dataset collection, any pH adjustment procedures used during the synthesis were also noted. In Fig. 6c, it is seen that majority of the data points do not involve any pH adjustment procedure. It is known that pH adjustment can be an effective approach to achieve strong metal-support interaction by adjusting the electrostatic interaction between them [39]. In Fig. 6c, the dispersion distribution of data points with and without any pH adjustment demonstrates this advantage. While the dispersion values of the dataset generally tend to accumulate in the range of 0–50 %, the dispersion distribution of the data points where pH adjustment was employed shows a wide range of possibility for controlling the palladium dispersion. Although only 20 % of data points involves pH adjustment, it is seen that high dispersions were also reported for these studies. 3.2 Development of the ML models for dispersion prediction Variable selection has a crucial role in model development. While ML creates an opportunity to work with systems having a high number of variables, the use of unnecessary variables must be avoided because the smaller models (with smaller descriptors) with acceptable accuracy are more robust for a given size of dataset. Hence, the potential contribution of variable was evaluated using Boruta algorithm [45]. As it is seen in Fig. 7 , all of the variables were found to be important, and, therefore, included in the RF models. The most important input variables were identified as Pd loading, support surface area, post-synthesis treatment conditions, and PZC, which reassure the domain knowledge on supported catalyst synthesis. Then the predictive models for Pd dispersion were built using various algorithms (linear regression, gradient boosting, RF regression, and decision tree regression); the RF model was decided to be the best option after comparing the fitness of all models tested. The dataset was divided into two groups as training and testing data. Train set contains 80 % of the dataset, which was randomly selected. The training dataset was further divided into five sub-datasets. While building the model with four of these datasets, the remaining dataset was used for validation. The process repeated five-times using 5-fold cross validation procedure under various values of model hyperparameters. After completing this step, the best model (i.e. the values of hyperparameters for the best prediction) were decided based on lowest RMSE, MAE and highest R2 results. Finally, the model was retrained using the entire training data and tested using the test set separated in the first step. The model is accessible in Github (https://github.com/kubra-tiras/Pd_CatalystSynthesis_ML_Model). Although average Pd nanoparticle size predictive model has been also developed, it is found to be less reliable compared to Pd dispersion model, which might be linked to the boundless range of average Pd nanoparticle size values. Hence, the following discussions are based on the predictive model for Pd dispersion. The model built with the number of trees of 500 and number of features of 5 was found to be the optimum resulting R2, RMSE, and MAE values of 0.8, 9.5, and 6.0 for the training set, respectively and R2, RMSE, and MAE values of 0.5, 14.9, and 10.2 for the testing set. The model predictions for training can be considered as quite good while it is also reasonable for testing, considering the complexities arising from the presence of multiple support and precursors in the dataset. However, as it is seen in Fig. 8 a and Fig. 8b, the model slightly overestimates the dispersion at low dispersion values (<40 %), while underestimating it at high dispersion values (>60 %) results. Apart from the measurement errors that may be in different level in low and high dispersion samples, some important input variable may be omitted due to the lack of relevant data or information. As previously stated by Moliner and colleagues when discussing ML techniques for zeolite synthesis, collecting experimental data is highly challenging, particularly when trying to cover the full range of real-life possibilities [60]. Thus, extracting data from the literature for these extreme points remains a challenge due to the lack of an automated system, and the low frequency of these extreme dispersion values impacts the model's performance in these regions. The model's predictive capability is particularly evident, especially given the challenges associated with working with experimental data reported by diverse research groups worldwide. Despite the inclusion of a large number of data points, experimental errors and standard deviations in measurements continue to exert a notable influence on the model's performance. The presented models are not only useful as predictive models, but also, they are good indicators for the need of data management methods in the heterogeneous catalysis area. As Marshall and coworkers suggested, adopting the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) data concept could improve data collection in the heterogeneous catalysis field, potentially enhancing the performance of models [12,61]. These models offer new opportunities for researchers to optimize their daily work and successfully synthesize the desired catalyst. Similar to Clerc and colleagues' approach of using meta-modeling for catalyst optimization, these models demonstrate that statistical algorithms are highly valuable for analysing experimental data in heterogeneous catalysis and present many prospects for future exploration [62]. 3.3 ARM for Input-Output relations ARM method was also applied to identify hidden relations between synthesis parameters and particle size, and to improve the explainability for RF model presented above. Average Pd nanoparticle size was categorized into four groups: <2, 2–5, 5–10, and >10 nm while input variables were discretized into maximum 7 categories which were discussed earlier in the Methodology Section. In ARM, lift values were used to understand whether there is a positive correlation between two variables by measuring the ratio between real and expected confidence values. Thus, if the corresponding lift value is higher than 1.0, it indicates that there is a positive correlation and if-then statement can be done [63]. If it is 1.0, then there is no significant correlation between parameters that can be stated [63]. The main results, which are mainly involved Pd precursor-solvent pairing, synthesis methods and surface area of support, are summarized here while the details of analysis are provided in SM. First, the results show that five correlations appear to be linked for precursor and solvent relation: Pd(acac)2 and toluene, PdCl2 and hydrochloric acid, PdCl2 and aqueous hydrochloric acid, Pd(NO3)2 and water, Pd(NH3)4 (NO3)2 and water with the lift values of 9.38, 2.50, 2.50, 1.50 and 1.17 respectively for the particle size smaller than 2 nm. The use of lift can be demonstrated using the strongest correlation identified as Pd(acac)2 and toluene; the lift value of 9.38 indicates that the fraction of the particle size <2 nm with the use of Pd(acac)2 and toluene together is 9.38 times higher than the fraction of particles size <2 nm in entire dataset indicating much higher probability to obtain small particles with Pd(acac)2 and toluene pair (the lift for Pd(acac)2 and toluene separately are found as 1.02 and 2.07, respectively). In Fig. 9 a, synthesis methods and average Pd nanoparticle size relations are illustrated; to make the effects of synthesis methods more apparent, we calculated the lift for each particle size and observed the change of lift with change of particle size. As can be clearly seen, the strongest correlation (lift value 2.49) for the particle sizes lower than 2 nm obtained with the use of deposition–precipitation method while liquid phase reduction and sol–gel can be also used to reduce the size (to lower 2–5 nm) with a lower lift; impregnation does not seem to be suitable to obtain smaller particles size (and therefore larger dispersion). Consequently, deposition–precipitation appears to be the best option for obtaining a lower average Pd nanoparticle size, which might be linked to applying pH adjustment procedure. Similar results were previously suggested by Huang and coworkers [53]. They stated the advantages of deposition–precipitation technique, and they compared 1 wt% Pd/TiO2 catalysts which were synthesized with impregnation and deposition–precipitation [53]. They indicated that deposition–precipitation offers a higher Pd dispersion compared to impregnation which was explained with strong metal-support interaction [53]. The relationship between the support’s surface area and average Pd nanoparticle size were also provided in Fig. 9b. Although no definitive conclusion can be obtained for the high surface area- particle size correlation, which may be complex as both may be dependent on various factors in synthesis, it can be safely said that lower surface area results in larger particle sizes indirectly indicating the high surface area-smaller particle size correlations. 3.4 Developing decision trees The impact of parameter selections done is complex and challenging to understand and describe solely through a predictive ML model. Especially, while looking at a specific support choice, predictive ML model is not capable to describe the influence of difference decisions made by the researchers. To overcome this issue, the decision trees specific to the supports (most common ones in the dataset) were developed. 80–20 % train-test split ratio and five-fold cross validation were used for the decision tree development. Hyperparameters of minsplit, cp, and maxdepth giving the highest accuracy and offering the simple representation were selected. Fig. 10 and Fig. 11 illustrate the diagrams for Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/C, respectively, with the corresponding confusion matrices provided in Tables S11–12 in the SM. These trees help identify combinations of synthesis parameters that lead to either high or low Pd dispersions on both supports. For example, the path leading to terminal node #21 on γ-Al2O3 shows that using solvents other than aqueous HCl, water, or acetone results in high dispersion when Pd loading and reduction temperature are kept below 1.6 wt% and 823 K, respectively, with 97 % accuracy (corresponding to 22 % of all Pd/γ-Al2O3 samples in the dataset). Our ARM analysis indicates that these solvents are typically associated with PdCl2, Pd(NO3)2, and Pd(acac)2, respectively, suggesting the use of precursors other than these for high dispersion. In contrast, terminal node #14 represents a combination of parameters leading to low dispersion, with 92 % accuracy (corresponding to 8 % of all Pd/γ-Al2O3 samples). To reach terminal node #14, when the metal loading exceeds 1.6 wt%, synthesis methods other than WI, IWI, Sol-gel, deposition–precipitation, and liquid-phase reduction result in low dispersion, even if the surface area is high. On Pd/C (Fig. 11), terminal node #7 indicates that using (NH3)4Pd(NO3)2 leads to high dispersion with 94 % accuracy, corresponding to 7 % of all Pd/C samples in the dataset. When using other precursors, a reduction temperature of ≤648 K leads to high dispersion if the support surface area is above 436 m2/g, as shown by the path to terminal node #26 (with 87 % accuracy, covering 11 % of all Pd/C samples). The path leading to terminal node #14 represents a combination of parameters for low dispersion on Pd/C. Specifically, long reduction times (over 1.8 h) result in low dispersion if any solvent other than acetone is used, even when the surface area is high (up to 1018 m2/g). Similarly, alternative paths to other terminal nodes in Figs. 10 and 11 allow for the evaluation of how different combinations of synthesis parameters affect Pd dispersion on these supports. 3.5 Validation of the ML models with new data from experiments and literature In addition to testing the model with the data explained above, the predictions were further validated using newly generated experimental results and up-to-date literature data that were not involved in any step of the model development. This testing was done to further assess the model's reliability. Initially, synthesis conditions were decided based on the dataset (considering common preferences) and Pd dispersion values for these planned experiments were predicted via the model which was improved by using a correction factor. Then, these predictions were compared with the dispersion results determined by the CO chemisorption measurements. The model was able to predict the experimentally measured Pd dispersion with 5.4 of RMSE and 4.7 of MAE. The comparison presented by green symbols in Fig. 8b proves the success and usability of the model in the daily work of researchers. Experiment results and corresponding predictions of the model were provided in Table S13, SI. Although these new experimental results demonstrate the model's effectiveness in making accurate predictions, they are limited to assessing the model's performance for a specific synthesis method, IWI. To evaluate the model's prediction capability for other synthesis methods, we used data from recent articles (published in 2024, after the dataset used to construct the model was collected). The comparison, shown by the red symbols in Fig. 8b, confirms the model’s success in predicting these new data points. The model performed well, predicting palladium dispersion with an MAE of 5.0 and an RMSE of 5.9. Therefore, we believe that the model presented here can serve as a valuable tool for researchers seeking to estimate metal dispersion on as-prepared catalysts based on their planned synthesis procedures. However, it is important to note that this model does not account for changes in catalyst structure due to sintering/redispersion or alterations in metal loading due to leaching in the working state of the catalysts. In addition to characterizing the as-prepared catalyst, it is crucial to characterize the catalyst in its working state to capture any structural changes that may occur during operation. 4 Conclusions Here, we developed a predictive ML model for Pd dispersion on a supported Pd catalyst based on the experimental data collected from 361 articles, with 1543 instances, 1295 of which were used for analysis. Pre-analysis identified key factors influencing Pd dispersion, including support choice (surface area), metal loading, and PZC. However, Pd dispersion cannot be predicted by a single parameter alone, as their combined effects are complex. Results showed that the WI and IWI methods typically yielded Pd dispersions of 0–40 %, though higher dispersions were also achievable. The deposition–precipitation method was more effective in achieving smaller Pd nanoparticle sizes, while alumina and cerium oxide supports produced higher dispersions. The toluene-Pd(acac)2 precursor pair was most common for catalysts with average nanoparticle sizes under 2 nm. The decision tree analysis, on the other hand, identifies key synthesis parameters that control Pd dispersion on both Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/C supports. For Pd/γ-Al2O3, high dispersion is achieved when solvents other than aqueous HCl, water, or acetone are used, with Pd loading and reduction temperature kept below 1.6 wt% and 823 K, respectively. On Pd/C, high dispersion is associated with the use of (NH3)4Pd(NO3)2 and a reduction temperature of ≤648 K when the support surface area exceeds 436 m2/g. Conversely, low dispersion on both supports is linked to specific precursor choices and synthesis methods, such as long reduction times or non-acetone solvents, even when the surface area is high. The RF regression model developed for Pd dispersion and nanoparticle size prediction demonstrated strong performance. Training and testing RMSE values were 9.5 and 14.9, respectively. Validation with catalysts synthesized using MgO, Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 as supports via the IWI method showed an RMSE of 5.4 and MAE of 4.7. Testing the model with recent data from other synthesis methods resulted in RMSE of 5.9 and MAE of 5.0, highlighting the model’s robustness. This model is a valuable tool for optimizing Pd catalyst synthesis, especially given the importance of Pd in industry and its high cost. It allows researchers to efficiently predict Pd dispersion and improve Pd utilization, while the dataset offers a comprehensive overview of the literature on supported Pd catalysts. Similar analysis can be also performed for the other critical catalyst properties and combined with kinetic information performance data for a specific reaction and used to predict performance under unknown conditions and develop heuristics to determine the conditions for high performance. coredata.dc:description: Supported palladium catalysts are indispensable in a wide range of industries, including petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and the automotive sector. The dispersion of palladium within these catalysts, primarily determined by the average nanoparticle size, significantly influences both the catalytic properties and the utilization efficiency of palladium. This study explores the relationships between various catalyst synthesis parameters and the resulting Pd nanoparticle size/dispersion. We developed a machine learning (ML) model to guide future synthesis efforts aimed at achieving specific palladium dispersion levels. Data were collected from previous studies on supported Pd catalysts published between 2000 and 2023, encompassing 1543 distinct catalysts. Of these, 1295 data points were used to construct the ML model. Key synthesis parameters—such as synthesis method, metal loading, support type, support surface area, metal precursor, solvent, solvent pH, support’s point of zero charge, and calcination/reduction conditions—were identified as independent variables, while dispersion and average Pd nanoparticle size served as dependent variables. A random forest (RF) regression model was employed to predict dispersion (in %), validated through 5-fold cross-validation. The model achieved root mean squared errors (RMSE) of 9.5 (training) and 14.9 (testing) in Pd dispersion (in %) prediction. Experimental synthesis of new supported palladium catalysts using different synthesis parameters confirmed the model’s predictions, yielding an RMSE of 5.4. Additionally, data from the literature published in 2024 were also used to validate the model, the comparison resulted in an RMSE of 5.9. This ML approach offers significant potential for precisely controlling palladium dispersion during catalyst synthesis, moving beyond traditional trial-and-error methods. It holds a broad potential to significantly improve palladium utilization across a variety of industrial applications.
